abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project was highly
            unsatisfactory, in light that no major project objective was
            achieved, nor is it expected to yield any significant
            development result. Thus, and due to the civil war,
            sustainability is unlikely, since the country will need to
            rebuild its physical infrastructure, as well as reconstitute
            the absence of institutions, and human capital. Although the
            Bank did restructure the project to fit the changing
            circumstances, the re-design relied on institutional, and
            policy reforms, which went beyond the government's
            capacity to implement. Lessons take the above into
            consideration, and suggest that it is preferable to cancel
            the original operation altogether, and, as circumstances
            evolve, prepare a small targeted operation, liable to
            address the existing emergency situation. The privatization
            of state monopolies, though necessary, is not sufficient for
            the prompt rise of private sector involvement in providing
            expected services. Rather, it is essential that incentives
            be provided for an expanded private sector participation.
            Under circumstances of civil crises, the report reinforces
            the importance for Bank support, to be based on close
            consultation, and coordination with other donors, to avoid
            duplication of efforts, and most importantly, to ensure a
            harmonious approach in providing its assistance.
